Section.Description: Under the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA), EPA has broad authority to issue regulations designed to require manufacturers (including importers) or processors to test chemical substances and mixtures for health and environmental effects.  This section provides information on test reports submitted for this chemical under TSCA.

Reference: E I DUPONT DE NEMOURS & CO INC; Delayed Neurotoxicity by Intramuscular Injection (Female Cats); 10/14/77; EPA Doc No. 878221338; Fiche No. OTS0215203

StringWithMarkup.String: Ortho-cresyl phosphate (CAS # 78-30-8) was evaluated for delayed neurotoxicity in two female cats administered 200 mg/kg bodyweight injections into the right shoulder. One cat initially injected subcutaneously with 0.22 mg/kg atropine sulfate in a hind leg to block an anticholinesterase reaction exhibited consistent weight loss for the first month following treatment. This cat also demonstrated rear leg extension and an unsteady gait with tail dragging during Days 31-61 post-injection. Upon Day 61 terminal sacrifice, histological evaluation of sciatic tibial and fibular nerves, sections of cerebrum, medulla, cerebellum and the cervical, thoracic and lumbar spinal cord revealed no significant changes. The second cat failed to demonstrate an anticholinesterase reaction or any treatment-related clinical signs throughout the 92-day post-treatment observation.

Reference: FMC CORP; The Acute Delayed Neurotoxic Effects of Inhalation of a Triaryl Phosphate, Lot 7-107 and of TOCP in the Domestic Hen; 7/8/79; EPA Doc No. 40-7942485; Fiche No. OTS0519270

StringWithMarkup.String: Tri-ortho-cresyl phosphate (CAS # 78-30-8) was evaluated for delayed inhalation neurotoxicity in adult domestic hens (Gallus domesticus) administered single whole-body exposures to graduated aerosol concentrations for 8 hours. Groups of 6 hens were supplied nominal concentrations of 0, 0.5, 1.0, 2.5 and 5.0 mg/L to assess a lowest level exposure inducing delayed locomotor ataxia in all treated birds. An identical trial was conducted to provide sufficient histological data. The mean measured graduated concentrations of tri-ortho-cresyl phosphate aerosol delivered in 2 parallel studies were 0.07, 0.13, 0.32 and 0.69, and 0.09, 0.20, 0.49 and 1.42 mg/L, respectively, and percent respirable particles ranged from 95.9 - 98.6%. Of the first study, 1 hen each died during or soon after 0.13 and 0.69 mg/L exposures. Mortality in the repeat study consisted of 1 hen each of the control and 0.49 mg/L exposure groups and 2 hens of 1.42 mg/L exposures. All, but one hen dying on Day 3 of a 1.42 mg/L exposure and a control hen, died during or soon after treatment. Birds exposed to concentrations at or above 0.13 mg/L demonstrated signs of respiratory distress during exposure including "gasping", occasional vigorous head-shaking and fluid from the beak and nostrils. Convulsions were observed in hens dying during the exposure period. Survivors of the aerosol exposures recovered from the initial signs of toxicity and subsequently demonstrated delayed neurotoxicity as moderate to severe ataxia in association with exposures to 0.20 mg/L or above. Ataxia was associated with exposures to 0.49 mg/L and higher. Marked bodyweight loss was also noted in hens of the high exposure groups. These delayed clinical findings were found to have positive histological correlates in dose-related degenerative changes of neurological tissues in all animals of 0.20 mg/L or greater exposures. Degenerative changes were limited to those hens of a 0.20 mg/L exposure that showed delayed clinical neuropathy and were unanimous among hens of higher exposures. Histopathology was characterized by degenerating fibers with myelinophages of sciatic nerve and cervical and/or thoracic spinal cord.

Reference: E.I. DU PONT DE NEMOURS & CO; Acute Skin Absorption on Rabbits - ALD, (1977), EPA Document No. 878221339, Fiche No. OTS0215203

StringWithMarkup.String: Acute dermal toxicity was evaluated in 15 male and female rabbits (strain not reported) receiving single occluded applications of undiluted tri-ortho-cresyl phosphate (TOCP) at dose levels of 5000 (2 male), 3400 (1 male), 2250 (1 male, 1 female), 1500 (1 male, 2 female), 1000 (1 male, 2 female), 670 (1 male, 1 female) and 450 (1 male, 1 female) mg/kg of body weight. The test article was held in contact with the intact skin for a 24-hour period. Mortality was observed in all animals in the three highest dose groups and 1 male and 1 female in both the 1500 and 1000 mg/kg dose group; the approximate lethal dose was reported to be 1000 mg/kg. Clinical observations included constriction of pupils, labored breathing, salivation, diarrhea, fasiculations, ataxia and prostration. Gross necropsy was not reported.

Reference: E.I. DU PONT DE NEMOURS & CO; Acute Skin Absorption on Cats - ALD, (1977), EPA Document No. 878221340, Fiche No. OTS0215203

StringWithMarkup.String: Acute dermal toxicity was evaluated in 4 female cats receiving single occluded applications of undiluted tri-o-cresyl phosphate at dose levels of 5000, 3400, 1500 and 1000 mg/kg of body weight. The test article was held in contact with the intact skin for a 24-hour period. Mortality was observed in animals in the two highest dose groups; the approximate lethal dose was reported to be 3400 mg/kg. Clinical observations included loss of appetite, weight loss, shallow breathing, and diarrhea. Histological examination of the sciatic, tibial and fibular nerves and sections of the spinal cord and brain revealed no evidence of neurotoxicity.

StringWithMarkup.String: /AQUATIC SPECIES/ Rainbow trout (Salmo gairdneri) were exposed to IMOL S-140, a synthetic high-temperature lubricating oil composed of tri-aryl phosphates and, although no sign of acute toxicity was evident, the fish slowly developed symptoms of chronic posioning. Section.Description: This section summarizes the environmental fate/exposure of this chemical, including the natural and artificial sources of the chemical as a pollutant, its environmental fate, biodegradation, abiotic degradation, bioconcentration, etc.

StringWithMarkup.String: Tri-o-cresyl phosphate's production and use as a plasticizer in lacquers and varnishes, in hydraulic fluids, as a flame retardant, gasoline additive, heat exchange medium, water proofing agent, and as a solvent for nitrocellulose may result in its release to the environment through various waste streams. If released to air, an estimated vapor pressure of 1.9X10-6 mm Hg at 25 °C indicates tri-o-cresyl phosphate will exist in both the vapor and particulate phases in the atmosphere. Vapor-phase tri-o-cresyl phosphate will be degraded in the atmosphere by reaction with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals; the half-life for this reaction in air is estimated to be 1.2 days. Monitoring studies have observed that tri-o-cresyl phosphate is removed from the atmosphere by both wet and dry deposition. Tri-o-cresyl phosphate does not absorb UV wavelengths >290 nm and, therefore, is not expected to be susceptible to direct photolysis by sunlight. If released to soil, tri-o-cresyl phosphate is expected to have no mobility based upon an estimated Koc of 4.7X10+4. Volatilization from moist soil surfaces is expected to be an important fate process based upon an estimated Henry's Law constant of 1.9X10-6 atm-cu m/mole. Tri-o-cresyl phosphate is not expected to volatilize from dry soil surfaces based upon its vapor pressure. Biodegradation in soil is expected to be an important fate based upon observed ready biodegradability in water and sediment. If released into water, tri-o-cresyl phosphate is expected to adsorb to suspended solids and sediment based upon the estimated Koc. Adsorption to suspended sediment and precipitation to bottom sediment was observed in sorption tests. Volatilization from water surfaces is expected to occur based upon this compound's estimated Henry's Law constant. Estimated volatilization half-lives for a model river and model lake are 87 and 640 days, respectively. An estimated BCF of 1060 suggests bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is very high, provided the compound is not metabolized by the organism. Hydrolysis might be an important fate process in alkaline waters; estimated hydrolysis half-lives are 1.2 years, 43 days and 4.3 days at pH 7, pH 8 and pH 9, respectively at 25 °C. Biodegradation is an important fate process. The half-life of tri-o-cresyl phosphate in lake water, river water and sediment bottoms has been observed to range from less than 3 to 12 days and tri-o-cresyl phosphate was readily biodegradable in sewage treatment and activated sludge studies. Occupational exposure may occur through dermal contact with tri-o-cresyl phosphate at workplaces where it is produced or used. Monitoring and use data indicate that the general population may be exposed to tri-o-cresyl phosphate via inhalation of ambient air, ingestion of food and drinking water, and dermal contact with consumer products containing tri-o-cresyl phosphate. (SRC)

Tricresyl phosphate's production and use as a plasticizer and flame retardant  in vinyl plastics, heat exchange medium, solvent for nitrocellulose, and as a hydraulic fluid and gasoline additive may result in its release to the  environment through various waste streams. If released to air, an extrapolated vapor pressure of 6.0X10-7 mm Hg at 25 °C indicates tricresyl phosphate will exist in both the vapor and particulate phases in the atmosphere. Vapor-phase tricresyl phosphate will be degraded in the atmosphere by reaction with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals; the half-life for this reaction in air is estimated to be 20 hours. Particulate-phase tricresyl phosphate will be removed from the atmosphere by wet and dry deposition. Tricresyl phosphate does not contain chromophores that absorb at wavelengths >290 nm and, therefore, is not expected to be susceptible to direct photolysis by sunlight. If released to soil, tricresyl phosphate is expected to be immobile based upon an estimated Koc of 4.5X10+4. Volatilization from moist soil surfaces is expected to occur based upon an estimated Henry's Law constant of 8.1X10-7 atm-cu m/mole. However, adsorption to soil is expected to attenuate volatilization. Tricresyl phosphate is not expected to volatilize from dry soil surfaces based upon its vapor pressure. Rapid biodegradation by activated sludge, with 40-60% degradation observed in a 48-hr wastewater treatment simulation, suggests that biodegradation may be an important environmental fate process in soil. If released into water, tricresyl phosphate is expected to adsorb to suspended solids and sediment based upon the estimated Koc. Using a river die-away study, 100% degradation after 4 days of incubation following a lag time of 2 days was observed, suggesting that biodegradation may be an important environmental fate process in acclimated water. Volatilization from water surfaces is expected to occur based upon this compound's estimated Henry's Law constant. Estimated volatilization half-lives for a model river and model lake are 87 and 640 days, respectively. However, volatilization from water surfaces is expected to be attenuated by adsorption to suspended solids and sediment in the water column. An BCF range of 165 to 3700 suggests bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is high to very high. Hydrolysis is expected to be an important environmental fate process in alkaline waters given estimated half-lives of 319 days at pH 7, 31.9 days at pH 8 and 3.19 days at pH 9. Occupational exposure to tricresyl phosphate may occur through inhalation, ingestion, and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where tricresyl phosphate is produced or used; skin penetration and accidental ingestion are the main routes of toxic exposure. Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be exposed to tricresyl phosphate  via inhalation of ambient air and dermal contact with his compound or consumer products containing tricresyl phosphate. (SRC)

StringWithMarkup.String: AQUATIC FATE: Based on a recommended classification scheme(1), an estimated Koc value of 4.7X10+4(SRC), determined from a structure estimation method(2), indicates that tri-o-cresyl phosphate is expected to adsorb to suspended solids and sediment in water(SRC). Tri-o-cresyl phosphate has been observed to adsorb to sediment in the water column and precipitate to the bottom in sorption studies(3). Volatilization from water surfaces is expected(4) based upon an estimated Henry's Law constant of 1.9X10-6 atm-cu m/mole(SRC), developed using a fragment constant estimation method(2). Using this Henry's Law constant and an estimation method(4), volatilization half-lives for a model river and model lake are 87 and 640 days, respectively(SRC). According to a classification scheme(5), an estimated BCF of 1060(SRC), from an estimated log Kow of 6.34(2) and a regression-derived equation(2), suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is very high, provided the compound is not metabolized by the organism(SRC). A base-catalyzed second-order hydrolysis rate constant of 0.16 L/mole-sec(SRC) and a neutral hydrolysis rate constant 2.33X10-6/day(SRC) were estimated using a structure estimation method(2); this corresponds to half-lives of 1.2 years, 43 days, 4.3 and 0.43 days at pH values of 7, 8, 9 and 10, respectively(2). The half-life of tri-o-cresyl phosphate in lake water, river water and sediment bottoms has been observed to range from less than 3 days to 12 days(6,7). Tri-o-cresyl phosphate was readily biodegradable in sewage treatment and activated sludge studies(8).

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental biodegradation for this compound. Biodegradation is the breakdown of organic matter by microorganisms, such as bacteria and fungi.  An important measure of biodegradability of wastewater is the biochemical oxygen demand (BOD), which is the amount of dissolved oxygen (DO) needed (i.e. demanded) by aerobic biological organisms to break down organic material present in a given water sample at certain temperature over a specific time period.

Reference: (1) Cho KJ et al; Water Sci Technol 30: 189-97 (1994)
(2) Howard PH, Deo PG; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 22: 337-44 (1979)
(3) Verschueren K; Handbook of Environmental Data on Organic Chemicals, 3rd ed, NY,NY: Van Nostrand Reinhold p. 1819 (1996)
(4) Sasaki S;pp. 283-98 in Aquatic Pollutants: Transformation and Biological Effects. Hutzinger O et al eds. Oxford: Pergamon Press (1978)

StringWithMarkup.String: AEROBIC: Biodegradation of tri-o-cresyl phosphate in river water and bottom sediment followed first-order kinetics(1). The first-order rate constant in river water ranged from approximately 0.0022 per hour at 14 °C to 0.0030 per hour at 25 °C(1); this corresponds to a half-life of about 13 days at 14 °C and 10 days at 25 °C(SRC). The first-order rate constant in bottom sediment ranged from approximately 0.0025 per hour at 14 °C to 0.0029 per hour at 25 °C(1); this corresponds to a half-life of about 12 days at 14 °C and 10 days at 25 °C(SRC). Tri-o-cresyl phosphate was completely degraded after 3 days of incubation in Lake Ontario water(2). 97% and 99% biodegradation of tri-o-cresyl phosphate occurred after 4 and 7 weeks, respectively, using an activated sludge seed and a tri-o-cresyl phosphate addition rate of 3 and 13 mg/L per 24 hours(3). In a river die-away test, using a tri-o-cresyl phosphate concentration of 26 mg/l, carbon dioxide evolution was 79% after 7 days, 82% after 28 days, and 86% after 48 days(3). In biodegradation tests using an activated sludge seed, tri-o-cresyl phosphate was observed to be biodegradable(4).

Reference: (1) Saeger VW et al; Environ Sci Technol 13: 840-4 (1979) 2) Wakabayashi M et al; Tukyo-To Kogai Kenkyusho Nenpo 1985: 125-8 (1985)
(2) Ishikawa S et al;  Suishitsu Odaku Kenkyu 8: 799-807 (1985)

StringWithMarkup.String: AEROBIC: Using a semi-continuous activated sludge test and a 4-week test duration, influent concentrations of 3 and 13 mg/L/day tricresyl phosphate were biodegraded (primary biodegradation) in excess of 97%(1). In a river die-away study using Mississippi river water from St Louis, MO, 100% of initial tricresyl phosphate degraded after 4 days of incubation(1); after an initial lag period of 2 days when only 8% had degraded, degradation proceeded rapidly probably due to microbial adaptation(1). In a CO2 evolution study using tricresyl phosphate, 78.6% of theoretical CO2 was evolved in 7 days and 82.1% in 28 days(1). Die-away studies using a Japanese river water and Japanese bay water found that 100% of initial tricresyl phosphate was degraded after 4 days of incubation at 26 °C; at 7 °C, 75-100% was degraded after 29 days of incubation. A lag period of 1-3 days was observed before rapid biodegradation commenced(2). Tricresyl phosphate was rapidly degraded by activated sludge (40-60%) in a 48-hr wastewater treatment simulation(3).

Reference: (1) Shelton DR, Tiedje JM; Development of Tests for Determining Anaerobic Biodegradation Potential. USEPA-560/5-81-013 (NTIS PB84-166495) (1981)

StringWithMarkup.String: ANAEROBIC: No tricresyl phosphate (meta-isomer) was observed to degrade in 8 weeks in 1:10 dilutions of primary anaerobic sludge(1).

Section.Description: Abiotic degradation is a process by which a chemical substance is broken down into smaller molecules by non-biotic means (e.g., hydrolysis, photolysis, and oxidation).

Reference: (1) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.10. Jan, 2011. Available from, as of Oct 2, 2012: https://www.epa.gov/oppt/exposure/pubs/episuitedl.htm

StringWithMarkup.String: The rate constant for the vapor-phase reaction of tri-o-cresyl phosphate with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals has been estimated as 1.4X10-11 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(SRC) using a structure estimation method(1). This corresponds to an atmospheric half-life of about 1.2 days at an atmospheric concentration of 5X10+5 hydroxyl radicals per cu cm(1). Phosphoric acid esters are susceptible to hydrolysis(2). A base-catalyzed second-order hydrolysis rate constant of 0.19 L/mole-sec(SRC) and a neutral hydrolysis rate constant 2.33X10-6/day were estimated using a structure estimation method(1); this corresponds to half-lives of 1.2 years, 43 days, 4.3 days and 0.43 days at pH values of 7, 8, 9 and 10, respectively(1). The UV spectra of triaryl phosphates do not show absorbance above 290 nm(3); therefore, tri-o-cresyl phosphate is not expected to be susceptible to direct photolysis by sunlight(SRC).

Reference: (1) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.10. Jan, 2011. Available from, as of Oct 9, 2012: https://www.epa.gov/oppt/exposure/pubs/episuitedl.htm
(2) Wolfe NL; Chemosphere 9: 571-6 (1980)
(3) Boethling RS, Cooper JC; Res Rev 94: 49-99 (1985)
(4) Howard PH, Deo PG; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 22: 337-44 (1979)
(5) Muir DCG et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 4: 663-75 (1985)
(6) Wagemann R; Verh Internat Verin Limnol 19: 2178 (1975)
(7) Ishikawa S et al; Suishitsu Odaku Kenkyu 8: 799-807 (1985)

StringWithMarkup.String: The rate constant for the vapor-phase reaction of tricresyl phosphate with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals has been estimated as 1.9X10-11 cu  m/molecule-sec at 25 °C(SRC) using a structure estimation method(1). This corresponds to an atmospheric half-life of about 20 hours at an atmospheric concentration of 5X10+5 hydroxyl radicals per cu cm(1). The second-order alkaline hydrolysis rate constant for tricresyl phosphate has been reported to be 0.27 k/M-1 sec-1 at 27 °C(2) which corresponds to half-lives of 319 days at pH 7, 31.9 days at pH 8 and 3.19 days at pH 9(SRC). Based on hydrolysis data for similar triaryl phosphates(3), the neutral hydrolysis half-life for tricresyl phosphate at 20-25 °C is on the order of 1 month or longer(SRC). A hydrolysis study using Lake Ontario water from Oswego, NY found that the individual isomers of tricresyl phosphate exhibited a two-day lag period before degrading rapidly(4); the ortho- and meta-isomers were totally degraded within 4 days while about half of the p-isomer was degraded in five days(4). Hydrolysis of aryl phosphates occurs by a stepwise release of aryl alcohols and phosphoric acids(4). Tricresyl phosphate does not absorb UV wavelengths >290 nm(5) and, therefore, is not expected to be susceptible to direct photolysis by sunlight(SRC). Limited experimental observations have suggested that the triaryl phosphates in aqueous solution, including tricresyl phosphate, may degrade more rapidly under sunlight exposure than in the dark(6,7); this degradation may be due to sensitized photolysis(SRC).

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental bioconcentration for this compound.  Bioconcentration is the accumulation of a chemical in or on an organism when the source of chemical is solely water. Bioconcentration is a term that was created for use in the field of aquatic toxicology. Bioconcentration can also be defined as the process by which a chemical concentration in an aquatic organism exceeds that in water as a result of exposure to a waterborne chemical.

Reference: (1) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.10. Jan, 2011. Available from, as of Oct 2, 2012: https://www.epa.gov/oppt/exposure/pubs/episuitedl.htm
(2) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)
(3) Muir DCG; in The Handbook of Environmental Chemistry; Anthropogenic Substances German: Springer-Berlag Berlin 3: 41-66 (1984)

StringWithMarkup.String: An estimated BCF of 1060 was calculated in fish for tri-o-cresyl phosphate(SRC), using an estimated log Kow of 6.34(1) and a regression-derived equation(1). According to a classification scheme(2), this BCF suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is very high, provided the compound is not metabolized by the organism(SRC). Depuration half-lives ranging from 4 to 6 days have been reported for the tricresyl phosphate isomers(3), indicating that tri-o-cresyl phosphate is expected to rapidly decrease in concentration when aquatic organisms are removed from contaminated water(SRC).

Reference: (1) Veith GD et al; J Fish Res Board Can 36: 1040-8 (1979)

StringWithMarkup.String: A BCF of 165 was measured for tricresyl phosphate in fathead minnows using a flow-through system and a 32-day exposure period(1). Using a flow-through system and a 14-day exposure period, a BCF of approximately 700 was observed in zebra fish (Brachydanio rerio)(2). Rainbow trout BCFs of 10 for white muscle and 169 for gut and adipose tissue were measured in a flow-through system using a commercial mixture (IMOL S-140) containing 75% tricresyl phosphate and 18% trixylyl phosphate(3). A tricresyl phosphate BCF of 3700 was measured in a static-system using Gambusia fish(3). In 24-hr static tests, tricresyl phosphate (meta- and para-isomers) BCFs of 784-1420 (in rainbow trout) and 596-928 (in fathead minnow) were measured based on total 14-Carbon(4); since the 14-Carbon measurements include tricresyl phosphate metabolites, the observed BCFs indicate a worse-case estimate only(3). According to a classification scheme(5), a BCF range of 165 to 3700 suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is high to very high(SRC). Depuration half-lives of tricresyl phosphate isomers range from 4 to 6 days(6).

Section.Description: Sorption to soils and sediments is an important factor on the transport and fate of organic contaminants in the environment.  The soil/water adsorption coefficient, also known as solid-water distribution coefficient (Kd), measures the amount of chemical substance adsorbed onto soil per amount of water.  Since adsorption occurs predominantly by partition into the soil organic matter, it is more useful to normalize the Kd value to the organic carbon content of a soil and express the distribution coefficient in Koc (organic carbon normalized distribution coefficient).  The greater the Kd (or Koc) value, the less likely a chemical will leach or contribute to runoff.  A very high value means it is strongly adsorbed onto soil and organic matter and does not move throughout the soil.

Reference: (1) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.10. Jan, 2011. Available from, as of Oct 2, 2012: https://www.epa.gov/oppt/exposure/pubs/episuitedl.htm
(2) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 23 (1983)
(3) Takimoto K et al; Environ Sci Technol 32: 3907-3912 (1998)
(4) Cho KM et al; Wat Sci Tech 30: 189-197 (1994)

StringWithMarkup.String: Using a structure estimation method based on molecular connectivity indices(1), the Koc for tri-o-cresyl phosphate can be estimated to be 4.7X10+4(SRC). According to a recommended classification scheme(2), this estimated Koc value suggests that tri-o-cresyl phosphate is expected to be immobile in soil(SRC). Tri-o-cresyl phosphate was found to adsorb strongly to clay minerals in sorption tests(3). Using bottom sediment from a river, tri-o-cresyl phosphate was found to adsorb strongly to the sediment with a Freundlich isotherm constant of 160(4); it was further observed that tri-o-cresyl phosphate in the water column adsorbed to sediment and precipitated to the bottom(4).

Reference: (1) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.10. Jan, 2011. Available from, as of Oct 8, 2012: https://www.epa.gov/oppt/exposure/pubs/episuitedl.htm
(2) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 23 (1983)

(5) Boethling RS, Cooper JC; Res Rev 94: 49-99 (1985)

StringWithMarkup.String: Using a structure estimation method based on molecular connectivity indices(1), the Koc for tricresyl phosphate can be estimated to be 4.5X10+4(SRC). According to a recommended classification scheme(2), this estimated Koc value suggests that tricresyl phosphate is expected to be immobile in soil(SRC). Using bottom sediment from a river, the tricresyl phosphate isomers were found to adsorb strongly to the sediment; it was further observed that tricresyl phosphate in the water column adsorbed to sediment and precipitated to the bottom(3). A sediment sorption constant (Kd) of 400 has been reported for tricresyl phosphate in a marine sediment(4). In aquatic persistence studies, tricresyl phosphate and other aryl phosphates have been observed to partition rapidly from the water column to sediment; concentrations in the sediment become much greater than concentrations in the water column(5).

Section.Description: Volatilization of chemicals from water/soil is the transfer of the chemical as a gas through the water-air or soil-air interface under environmental conditions

StringWithMarkup.String: The Henry's Law constant for tri-o-cresyl phosphate is estimated as 1.9X10-6 atm-cu m/mole(SRC) using a fragment constant estimation method(1). This Henry's Law constant indicates that tri-o-cresyl phosphate is expected to volatilize from water surfaces(2). Based on this Henry's Law constant, the volatilization half-life from a model river (1 m deep, flowing 1 m/sec, wind velocity of 3 m/sec)(2) is estimated as 87 days(SRC). The volatilization half-life from a model lake (1 m deep, flowing 0.05 m/sec, wind velocity of 0.5 m/sec)(2) is estimated as 640 days(SRC). Tri-o-cresyl phosphate's Henry's Law constant indicates that volatilization from moist soil surfaces is not expected to occur(SRC). Tri-o-cresyl phosphate is not expected to volatilize from dry soil surfaces based on a vapor pressure of 1.96X10-6 mm Hg at 25 °C(3).

Reference: (1) Boethling RS, Cooper JC; Res Rev 94: 49-99 (1985)
(2) Saeger VW et al; Environ Sci Technol 13: 840-4 (1979)
(3) Lyman WJ et al; Handbook of Chemical Property Estimation Methods Washington DC: Amer Chem Soc pp. 15-15 to 15-29 (1990)
(4) U.S. EPA; EXAMS II Computer Simulation (1987)

StringWithMarkup.String: The Henry's Law constant for tricresyl phosphate is estimated as 8.1X10-7 atm-cu m/mole(SRC) derived from its extrapolated vapor pressure, 6.0X10-7 mm Hg at 25 °C(1), and water solubility, 0.36 mg/L(2). This Henry's Law constant indicates that tricresyl phosphate is expected to volatilize from water surfaces(3). Based on this Henry's Law constant, the volatilization half-life from a model river (1 m deep, flowing 1 m/sec, wind velocity of 3 m/sec)(3) is estimated as 87 days(SRC). The volatilization half-life from a model lake (1 m deep, flowing 0.05 m/sec, wind velocity of 0.5 m/sec)(3) is estimated as 640 days(SRC). The estimated  volatilization half-life from a model pond is greater than 20 years when adsorption is considered(4). Tricresyl phosphate's Henry's Law constant indicates that volatilization from moist soil surfaces is not expected to be an important fate process(SRC). Tricresyl phosphate is not expected to volatilize from dry soil surfaces based on its vapor pressure(SRC).

Literature references related to scientific contents from Springer Nature journals and books. It is based on: (1) the TF-IDF, adapted to chemical structures, (2) location information in the text (e.g. title, abstract, keywords), and (3) the document size.  Springer Nature aims to provide only highly qualitative and relevant content but references of lower relevance aren't withheld as they might contain also very useful information.

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.
Reference.LicenseNote: CC-BY 4.0
